title: Clinique Happy font?
content:
Would anyone know (know, not guess!) which font was used for the CLINIQUE HAPPY perfume product design, and subsequent advertising campaign? Thank you!   
   
 ![Clinique Happy Ad](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/28051.jpg)
author: anonymous

comments.content:
Now that's Palatino.   
   
The first sample you posted, however, is not Palatino.

Exactly. The first one looks like [Century Schoolbook](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/century-schoolbook), whereas the second sample you posted is [Palatino](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/palatino).

Hmmm... some kind of [Century](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/century-schoolbook/century-schoolbook/testdrive.html?s=clinique%20happy%20heart&p=48) face. [But which one?](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126/http:/www.myfonts.com/Search?searchtext=century) I don't   
understand the serif on the "c", it should be ball-shaped.

Here is a bit more from their website: - still convinced about century?   
 ![More Clinique](http://web.archive.org/web/20141003050126im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/28061.gif)
Looking at the two samples again, I notice that they seem to have changed face mid-project? The two faces are wildly different, - leaves me baffled!?
Yeah, it looks pretty much like Century Schoolbook, but the 'c' got me puzzled.
